I'll produce final answer accordingly.</think>Below is one way of “dissecting” the puzzle step‐by‐step:

 • First note that
  k₉ = 467 and k₁₀ = 514.
  Since 514 – 47 = 467, we immediately have

   k₉ = k₁₀ – 47.

This shows that the difference between k₁₀ and k₉ is exactly 47. (And since 47 itself is prime, its appearance as this “step” or increment may be no accident in a key‐generation scheme.)

 • Next, one way to “write” a number is to express it in the form

  some_key × M + C.
  
For example, notice that if we try a multiplier M = 9 then
  9 × 49 = 441,
and since 467 – 441 = 26 we have

  467 = 49 × 9 + 26.

One may interpret the “some_key” here as k₆ (if indeed the keys are being used in that order) so that this representation is

  k₉ = k₆×9 + 26.
  
(Incidentally, note that 26 factors as 2×13; such factorizations sometimes play a role in number‐theoretic puzzles.)

 • One may try other small multipliers (M = 7 gives 467 = 66×7 + 5, M = 17 gives 467 = 27×17 + 8, etc.), but the representation above is especially neat because 9 and 26 come up in another formula (namely for k₁₀) and hint at a deeper structure.

 • In summary, one “simplest” answer is to note that since

  k₉ = k₁₀ – 47,
  
the number 47 (which appears as the constant difference between two keys and also factors into other formulas) may be viewed as fundamental. And indeed, writing

  467 = 49×9 + 26
gives one linear representation of k₉.

Thus, the simplest answer to “what is k₉?” is simply that it is given by

  k₉ = k₁₀ – 47,
or equivalently, since k₁₀ = 514, we have k₉ = 467. 

This step‐by‐step explanation shows both that the difference of 47 is “built in” and that one acceptable linear representation is

  k₉ = k₆×9 + 26,
with k₆ = 49.
